title: 107_hr14
content: The Act may be cited as the "Bipartisan Commission on Social Security Reform Act of 2001". The Congress acknowledges the projected depletion of the Social Security trust funds by 2037 due to demographic factors such as the retirement of baby boomers and increased life expectancy. Policymakers would need to consider raising taxes, cutting spending, or borrowing money to address this issue. Social Security reform is deemed necessary due to concerns about its long-term sustainability and value. Despite the urgency, there is no consensus on how to achieve this, as evidenced by various proposals and bills introduced in Congress. The administration and Congress have proposed various approaches to Social Security reform, but there has been no progress due to differences. To address this, a Bipartisan Commission on Social Security Reform will be established to develop a unified proposal for long-term retirement security. Established in the legislative branch, the Bipartisan Commission on Social Security Reform is tasked with designing recommendations for long-term solvency and retirement income security in the United States. The Bipartisan Commission on Social Security Reform consists of 17 members selected by various leaders in the government, including the Speaker of the House, the Senate majority leader, the House minority leader, the Senate minority leader, and the President. The Bipartisan Commission on Social Security Reform consists of 17 members selected by government officials and private citizens. Members must have recognized standing, represent different generations, and have the capacity to fulfill their duties. At least one member must represent employees and one must represent employers. The officials mentioned in subsection (a) will designate a Chair for the Commission. The Bipartisan Commission on Social Security Reform consists of 17 members appointed within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Members serve for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. SEC. 6. PROCEDURES. The Commission shall meet as called by its Chair or majority of members. Once 9 members are appointed, they can select the Chair to start operations, including hiring staff. A quorum consists of 9 members, but fewer can conduct hearings. The Commission may hold hearings and other activities as needed to fulfill its duties. It can request information from the Commissioner of Social Security and other agencies. The Commissioner of Social Security and other federal agencies must provide necessary information to the panel for carrying out its duties. SEC. 7. ADMINISTRATION. Members of the Commission do not receive additional pay, allowances, or benefits, except for travel expenses and per diem. The staff director is appointed by the Chair and compensated at a specified rate. The Commission staff, including the staff director, can appoint additional personnel as needed. They are exempt from certain civil service laws and pay regulations. Experts and consultants can be hired with approval. The staff director of the Commission can procure temporary services with approval. The Architect of the Capitol will provide office space and necessary equipment for the Commission. Administrative support services will be provided nonreimbursable upon request. The Commission may receive administrative support services, funds, facilities, staff, and other assistance from US departments and agencies as authorized by law. It can use the United States mails and printing services as if it were a committee of Congress. The Commission will submit a report to the House of Representatives and Senate within 6 months of its first meeting, including findings, conclusions, and recommendations. The report must be approved by at least nine members. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting its final report. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of appropriations for the Commission activities is granted, with $2,000,000 available from existing funds until specific appropriations are made.
